description: A general introduction to the nature, history and use of human language, speech and writing. Topics include the biological basis of human language, and analogous systems in other creatures; relations to cognition, communication, and social organization; sounds, forms and meanings in the world s languages; the reconstruction of linguistic history and the family tree of languages; dialect variation and language standardization; language and gender; language learning by children and adults; the neurology of language and language disorders; the nature and history of writing systems. Intended for any undergraduate interested in language or its use, this course is also recommended as an introduction for students who plan to major in linguistics.
name: INTRO TO LINGUISTICS

values.comments:
This course is perfect for any student interested in languages because it offers a general introduction to the history, structure, and science behind written and spoken language. A large focus is paid to the structure of sounds, words, and sentences. Students will also learn about the language acquisition process and the evolution of languages, and be able to compare it to animal communication systems. For students in the College of Arts & Sciences, the course satisfies the General Requirement in Living World (Sector V).
Homework is assigned almost on a weekly basis and counts for 40% of the grade. Overall, students were frustrated at how difficult the assignments were because these usually tested concepts that were not covered during lectures. Students are required to buy a bulk pack containing required readings that were found to be engaging and well written.
Some students described the pace of the class as “too fast” for an introductory course. Professors Embick was criticized for “read[ing] straight from the powerpoint” and putting too much material on the slides. Students also wanted the professor to make lecture more lively and engaging for they considered his lectures “painstakingly detailed.”
Although students found the class to be difficult, they also said the course was interesting and enjoyable for both majors and non-majors.
